title: How to Cite a Syllabus in APA

steps.title: List the university or college first.
steps.content: List the university or college first. You should use the full name of the university or college where you took the course. Write it out in plain Roman letters (no italics) and end the name of the institution with a period. [1] X Research source For example, if you took the course at the University of Michigan, you would write “The University of Michigan.” Just writing “Michigan.” isn’t correct.

steps.title: Indicate the year you took the course in parentheses.
steps.content: Indicate the year you took the course in parentheses. You don’t need the semester, just the year you took the course. Write the year in regular Roman letters (no italics) within parentheses and then add a period. [2] X Research source For example, if you took the course in the fall of 2010, you would just write “(2010).” after the name of the institution.

steps.title: Write the name of the course in italics.
steps.content: Write the name of the course in italics. You should include the course name and number, as well as the full title of the course, in italics. Only the first letter of the first word of the title and subtitle should be capitalized. Then end the title with a period. [3] X Research source Say that you’re taking a history course. The name and number is HIST 101, and the title of the course is “The Ancient World.” You would write that as “ HIST 101: The ancient world .”

steps.title: Indicate that the source is a syllabus.
steps.content: Indicate that the source is a syllabus. If the title of your syllabus actually says “course syllabus,” you should include that in the name of the course. If the title of your syllabus is just the title of the course, indicate that it’s a course syllabus in brackets. [4] X Research source For example, if your course syllabus says “course syllabus” in the title, you would write it as: “ HIST 101: The ancient world course syllabus .” If “course syllabus” isn’t part of the title, you would write “ HIST 101: The ancient world [Course syllabus].”

steps.title: Write where the course took place.
steps.content: Write where the course took place. This should be the same place where you took the class. You can write the city, U.S. state (if applicable), and country. End this portion with a colon. [5] X Research source For example, if you took the course at the University of Michigan, you would write “Ann Arbor, Michigan:”

steps.title: End with the name of your professor.
steps.content: End with the name of your professor. After the colon after the location of the course, you need to indicate where you got the source from. This should be the name of the instructor teaching the course. For example, if your instructor is Professor Anita Smith, you would write “Anita Smith.”

steps.title: Skip the location and author title if your syllabus was retrieved online.
steps.content: Skip the location and author title if your syllabus was retrieved online. If your syllabus was available online and that’s where you got it, the end of the citation is slightly different. Instead of writing the physical location of the university and the author’s name, write a retrieval statement. [6] X Research source For example, if you got your syllabus off of the website Blackboard, after the title of the course (with or without the [Course syllabus] indication), you would write “Available from The University of Michigan Blackboard website: umich.blackboard.edu.” The entire citation would therefore look like this: “ HIST 101: The ancient world [Course syllabus]. Available from The University of Michigan Blackboard website: umich.blackboard.edu.”

steps.title: Indent any lines after the first.
steps.content: Indent any lines after the first. If you find that your citation takes up more than one line, you’ll need to indent any subsequent lines. This lets your reader see where one source ends and another begins. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Start with your instructor’s last name if there is one.
steps.content: Start with your instructor’s last name if there is one. If your works cited page citation includes an author’s name, use it for your in-text citation. Start with an open parenthesis, then the author’s last name, followed by a comma. [8] X Research source For example, if your instructor’s name is Anita Smith, the first part of your citation should look like this: “(Smith,”

steps.title: List the institution first if there isn’t an instructor name.
steps.content: List the institution first if there isn’t an instructor name. If you’re not using an instructor/author name on your works cited page, list the institution where you took the course. It should follow the same format as if you were using an instructor’s name. [9] X Research source For example, if you don’t have an instructor’s name on your works cited page, but you took the course at The University of Michigan, you would write “(The University of Michigan,”

steps.title: Write the year you took the course.
steps.content: Write the year you took the course. This should match the year you list on your reference page for the course. You don’t need to indicate the semester you took the course, just the year. [10] X Research source If you took the course in 2013, you would write “(Smith, 2013” or “(The University of Michigan, 2013”

steps.title: List the page numbers you’re referencing.
steps.content: List the page numbers you’re referencing. To end your in-text citation, you’ll need to indicate which pages you’re referencing in your text. It might be 1 page or multiple pages, and that’s fine, as long as you list them all. Write a lower-case “p,” followed by a period, and then the page number. Then end the citation with a closed parenthesis. [11] X Research source For example, if the information you’re citing is on page 1 of the syllabus, you would write “(Smith, 2013, p. 1).” or “(The University of Michigan, 2013, p. 1).” If you’re citing more than one page, use “pp.” instead of “p.” So your citation would look like this: “(The University of Michigan, 2013, pp. 4-5).”

steps.title: Mention the author’s name in the text.
steps.content: Mention the author’s name in the text. If you’re integrating the citation into the text you’re writing, you’ll need the author’s name. There are quite a few ways to do this, and how you do it will depend on your own personal preference and the tone of your paper. [12] X Research source For example, you could say something like “According to Smith...” or “Smith argues that the study of history...”

steps.title: Include the year cited on the reference page immediately after the author’s name.
steps.content: Include the year cited on the reference page immediately after the author’s name. Regardless of how you incorporate the author’s name in your text, it needs to be followed immediately by the year you use on your reference page. This lets your reader know immediately which source you’re talking about. [13] X Research source For example, you would write “According to Smith (2013),” or “Smith (2013) argues that the study of history...”

steps.title: Set off direct quotes with quotation marks.
steps.content: Set off direct quotes with quotation marks. If you’re citing directly from the syllabus, set that information apart with quotation marks. This lets your reader know that these words aren’t yours, but the author’s. [14] X Research source For example, you could write: According to Smith (2013), the study of history is “fundamental to understanding the present.” If you’re using your own words instead of the author’s, you don’t need quotation marks. So you might write “According to Smith (2013), we can only understand the present if we understand history.”

steps.title: End the citation with the page number or numbers.
steps.content: End the citation with the page number or numbers. Once you’ve cited the part of the syllabus you need, end the citation with the page number or numbers where the citations can be found. The page number should set apart by parentheses, a lower case p, followed by a period. [15] X Research source Your citation might look like this: “According to Smith (2013), the study of history is “fundamental to understanding the present” (p. 4).
